Scalable and multiplexed recorders of gene regulation dynamics across weeks

title: Defending endangered trees against climate change and hungry goats
content:
Nature, Published online: 26 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00248-x

Mohammed Amar manages conservation of imperilled flora in Socotra, a Yemeni island known as the Galápagos of the Indian Ocean.

title: Quantum spinning effect observed in a levitating magnet
content:
Nature, Published online: 26 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00208-5

A supercooled microscopic ferromagnet proves the existence of gyroscopic magnetic behaviour that has been long sought by physicists.

title: Audio long read: ‘I rarely get outside’ — scientists ditch fieldwork in the age of AI
content:
Nature, Published online: 26 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00255-y

In the wake of new computer-based methods, some ecologists fear their field is losing touch with nature.

title: Why do women like me get diagnosed with ADHD late?
content:
Nature, Published online: 26 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00260-1

Emily Bates was diagnosed with ADHD at the age of 34. She explores how the condition presents in women and why so many are diagnosed later in life.

title: Technology is changing how we write — and how we think about writing
content:
Nature, Published online: 26 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00245-0

An exploration of how writing systems, from ancient Chinese characters to modern alphabets, shape language, and whether users of ChatGPT can be said to be authors at all.

title: As we breach 1.5 °C, we must replace temperature limits with clean-energy targets
content:
Nature, Published online: 26 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00246-z

Actionable goals are needed to guide the world towards what needs to happen most quickly: shifting economies to clean energy sources.

title: Exceeding 1.5 °C requires rethinking accountability in climate policy
content:
Nature, Published online: 26 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00247-y

A scientific foundation is required to establish nations’ responsibilities in a hotter ‘overshoot’ world.

title: Daily briefing: Why cancer might protect against Alzheimer’s disease
content:
Nature, Published online: 23 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00257-w

A protein made by cancer cells seems to break down the hallmark plaques of Alzheimer’s disease. Plus, our breath might reveal what’s going on in our gut and the controversy surrounding a US-funded hepatitis B vaccine trial in Guinea-Bissau.

title: Daily briefing: Largest ever ‘superposition’ pushes quantum boundary
content:
Nature, Published online: 22 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00242-3

Physicists have shown that a quantum object can be at least as big as a cluster of 7,000 sodium atoms. Plus, the oldest-known cave art in the world and why girls are starting puberty earlier than ever.

title: A highly integrated blade structure for thermoelectric devices with ultra-high output voltage and power densities
content:
Energy Environ. Sci., 2026, Advance Article
DOI: 10.1039/D5EE06920C, Paper
Chuanyao Sun, Pengfei Qiu, Xinjie Yuan, Kelin Shen, Yi Wu, Xuefeng Zhao, Jiawei Zhang, Shiqi Yang, Lidong Chen, Xun Shi
We propose a highly integrated blade-like structure, which includes thin and long thermoelectric legs like a blade. This novel structure enables ultrahigh output voltage and power densities when the device is worn on the human body.
To cite this article before page numbers are assigned, use the DOI form of citation above.
The content of this RSS Feed (c) The Royal Society of Chemistry
journal: RSC - Energy Environ. Sci. latest articles

title: Alcohol-dispersed conductive polymer for high-performance organic photovoltaic cells
content: By tailoring solute-solvent interactions, the isopropanol-dispersed PEDOT-OH:PSS was developed. It exhibits excellent wettability on hydrophobic flexible substrates. Serving as an interconnecting layer in conventional tandem organic photovoltaic cells, it enables an efficiency of up to 21.7%, representing the highest reported performance in the organic photovoltaic field to date.

title: Stabilizing α-FAPbI3 perovskite via centered formamidinium cation immobilization
content: Pyrene at perovskite grain boundaries immobilizes formamidinium cations, stabilizing the PbI6 cage and rigidifying α-FAPbI3. Rigid α-FAPbI3 exhibited a uniform spatioenergetic landscape, reduced electron-phonon coupling, facilitated efficient charge transport, and suppressed perovskite degradation. Pyrene-incorporated α-FAPbI3 retained its photoactive phase with over 25% power conversion efficiency and operational stability exceeding 3,400 h.

title: Zinc oxides reinforced silicon anodes for high-performance all-solid-state lithium-ion batteries
content:
EES Batteries, 2026, Accepted Manuscript
DOI: 10.1039/D5EB00238A, Paper
Open Access
  This article is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 3.0 Unported Licence.
RenBo Liu, Chaolin Mi, Xiaobo Jiang, Shijian Xiong, Zhengyang Song, Yuanchang Shi, Xiaohang Lin, Peng Xiao, Long-Wei Yin, Rutao Wang
Silicon is a promising candidate as an anode material for all-solid-state lithium batteries (ASSLBs) due to its high theoretical specific capacity (~3500 mAh g-1), low cost and abundant earth reserves....

title: The paradoxes of interfacial electrolyte structures
content:
Nature Materials, Published online: 26 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02468-4

Charge frustration emerges as a key factor to explain the formation of overcharged ion structures next to an electrified surface.

title: Achieving high tensile strength and ductility in refractory alloys by tuning electronic structure
content:
Nature Materials, Published online: 26 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02464-8

Guided by density functional theory, a commercially viable refractory alloy is developed, which exhibits excellent room-temperature ductility and strength, and high strength at elevated temperatures.

title: How charge frustration causes ion ordering and microphase separation at surfaces
content:
Nature Materials, Published online: 26 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02467-5

Atomic force microscopy is used to investigate the adsorption and organization of ions on charged surfaces. Trivalent ions adopt complex networks, clusters and layers associated with overcharging, whereas divalent ions follow classical predictions.

title: Electrochemical reduction of PFAS
content:
Nature Chemistry, Published online: 26 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41557-026-02069-x

Mineralization of per-and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) to inorganic fluorides is challenging. Now, a lithium metal-mediated electrochemical reduction route is reported that degrades and defluorinates PFAS with high efficiency. Additionally, the fluoride released from the reactive metal-based reaction can be upcycled to a non-PFAS fluorinated product in a circular fluorine loop.

title: Current-assisted dual-atom catalyst sequentially boosts low-temperature propane combustion through atomic relay
content:
Nature Chemistry, Published online: 26 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41557-025-02062-w

The efficient low-temperature combustion of stable alkanes remains a major challenge in catalysis. Now it has been shown that a Pt–Nb dual-atom catalyst enables propane combustion through a distinct stepwise-boosting, current-assisted atomic relay mechanism, yielding complete conversion below 200 °C and a high turnover frequency.
